table.description: Identifies inefficiencies and potential cost reductions affecting production expenses.
Non-compliance incidents can lead to penalties, rework, scrapping costs, and additional quality-related expenses, directly impacting operational profitability.

table.insight: Quality Rejected Items Issued to Production
table.description: Using defective materials increases wastage and rework, resulting in higher production costs or losses, directly impacting profitability.
Low recovery increases material usage per output, leading to higher cost of production, increased variance losses, and reduced gross margins. This directly affects profitability.
Fraudulent or duplicate payments inflate expenses.
Lack of competitive bidding may result in inflated prices.

table.insight: Procurement of Contracted Material at Higher Price
table.description: Higher material costs.

table.insight: Invoice Date Prior to PO Date
table.description: Expenses may be recognized in the wrong period or without a valid PO, distorting financial results.
Fragmented orders may result in inconsistent expense recognition or concealment of high-value purchases.
Duplicate or unauthorized payments increase expense totals.
Unverified or duplicate payments can lead to overstated expenses.
Duplicate or unapproved expenses inflate overall costs.

table.insight: Some Expenses for PO and Non PO transaction
table.description: Higher material prices in some plants increase overall production cost.

table.insight: Inter Plant Variation in Material Price
table.description: Expenses may be recorded higher/lower than actual agreed rate or quantity.

table.insight: Deviation in liability compares to base rate and quantity
table.description: Paying for goods not received.
Sale of expired items often occurs at discounted prices or as scrap, reducing revenue and increasing potential losses or write-offs in the income statement.

If such transfers are not correctly accounted for, they may result in over/understatement of expenses (e.g., duplicate or missing vendor payments) or income adjustments (in case of customer transfers).
The same expense is recorded more than once, inflating total expenses and reducing reported profit for the fiscal year.

table.insight: Repeated Vendor Invoice in the Same Fiscal Year
table.description: Misstated shelf life can delay or accelerate recognition of inventory losses, distorting gross margin and profitability.

table.insight: Multiple Shelf Life for Some Material/Batch
table.description: When actual material consumption differs significantly from the standard, it causes inaccurate cost recording. Overconsumption inflates production costs, reducing gross profit; underconsumption may lead to overstated profits.

table.insight: Deviation in Standard v/s Actual Consumption
table.description: A higher actual yield loss compared to the standard yield loss indicates production inefficiency or wastage. This increases production cost and reduces inventory valuation, impacting gross profit. Lower actual loss than standard improves margins.

table.insight: Actual Yield Loss v/s Standard Yield Loss
table.description: If event log discrepancies result in incorrect consumption or production entries, it can cause inaccurate expense recognition (COGS) or unrecorded inventory losses/gains, impacting profitability.
Inefficiency costs.

table.insight: Inconsistence Performance Metrics and KPIs across units
table.description: Downtime/Rework costs.
Downtime/Rework costs.
